newsitem.title: USA: N.J. Gov touts local benefits of bond plan - paper.
newsitem.headline: N.J. Gov touts local benefits of bond plan - paper.

text.p: New Jersey Gov. Christine Whitman is trying a new tack in pitching her $2.75 billion pension bond plan -- the benefits to local governments, the Bergen Record reported Wednesday.

After the Senate cancelled a vote on the controversial measure Monday, Whitman began highlighting a component of the plan that she said could save municipal and county governments $107 million in pension costs next year.
Local governments enrolled in the state Public Employee Retirement System would be allowed to skip next year's pension payments under an amendment added to the Whitman plan.

Savings would range from $2.8 million for Bergen County to $728 for the Edgewater Park Sewerage Authority. The state is hoping to save $647 million with essentially the same strategy, after selling $2.75 billion of bonds to pay off the pension system's unfunded liability.

Sen. Bernard Kenny Jr., D-Hoboken, blasted Whitman's new local government push as a "desperate attempt to salvage her troubled pension bond sale proposal by offering local governments yet another fiscal gimmick."
The Senate's next opportunity to vote on the measure is May 8.
